July 6, 2003: Fiction
THE DA VINCI CODE, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The murder of a
curator at the Louvre leads to a trail of clues found in the work of Leonardo and to
the discovery of a centuries-old secret society.
THE LAKE HOUSE, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $27.95.) Six children
living in the Rocky Mountains are forced to flee a dangerous, evil force.
WHITE DEATH, by Clive Cussler with Paul Kemprecos. (Putnam, $26.95.) While
attempting to rescue a ship full of trapped men, Kurt Austin and a colleague
uncover a sinister corporation's plot to control the world's oceans.
THE DEVIL WEARS PRADA, by Lauren Weisberger. (Doubleday, $21.95.) A
young woman acquires a job at a fashion magazine, along with the boss from hell.
THE LOVELY BONES, by Alice Sebold. (Little, Brown, $21.95.) A 14-year-old girl
looks down from heaven as she describes what happens in the aftermath of her
kidnapping and murder.
THE FACE, by Dean Koontz. (Bantam, $26.95.) A police officer turned security
chief must protect a handsome Hollywood star whose life has been threatened.
DIE IN PLAIN SIGHT, by Elizabeth Lowell. (Morrow, $24.95.) After inheriting a set
of landscapes painted by her enigmatic grandfather, a woman discovers that the
paintings contain clues to a series of unexplained murders.
THE GUARDIAN, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $24.95.) While trying to choose
between two suitors, a young widow realizes that her life is in danger.
THE KING OF TORTS, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) A public defender
in Washington happens upon a frightening conspiracy.
THE DOGS OF BABEL, by Carolyn Parkhurst. (Little, Brown, $21.95.) A linguist
tries to unravel the mystery of his wife's death by communicating with the only
witness to it, their dog.
NAKED PREY, by John Sandford. (Putnam, $26.95.) Lucas Davenport
investigates the apparent lynching of a black man and a white woman in
Minnesota.
ARMAGEDDON, by Tim LaHaye and Jerry B. Jenkins. (Tyndale, $24.99.) The
11th volume of the "Left Behind" series, in which the forces of good battle the
forces of evil after the rapture of the saved.
FLIRTING WITH PETE, by Barbara Delinsky. (Scribner, $26.) A woman inherits a
town house and an intriguing manuscript from the father she never knew.
THE SINISTER PIG, by Tony Hillerman. (HarperCollins, $25.95.) With help from
July 6, 2003
Non-Fiction
LIVING HISTORY, by Hillary Rodham Clinton. (Simon & Schuster, $28.) A memoir
by the junior senator from New York and former first lady.
A SHORT HISTORY OF NEARLY EVERYTHING, by Bill Bryson. (Broadway,
$27.50.) From the Big Bang to the 21st century: a guided tour of the sciences and
what they tell us about the physical world.
MONEYBALL, by Michael Lewis. (Norton, $24.95.) How Billy Beane, the general
manager of the Oakland Athletics, produces a successful team despite having one
of the smallest payrolls in baseball.
BEYOND BELIEF, by Elaine Pagels. (Random House, $24.95.) The author of
"The Gnostic Gospels" examines early Christianity through the Gospel of Thomas.
AN UNFINISHED LIFE, by Robert Dallek. (Little, Brown, $30.) A biography of John
F. Kennedy by a professor of history at Boston University.
WHO'S YOUR CADDY? by Rick Reilly. (Doubleday, $24.95.) A sportswriter
recounts his experiences caddying for (among others) Jack Nicklaus, David Duval,
Bob Newhart and Deepak Chopra.
THE TEAMMATES, by David Halberstam. (Hyperion, $22.95.) The story of a
friendship among four men who played for the Red Sox in the 1940's: Ted
Williams, Dom DiMaggio, Johnny Pesky and Bobby Doerr.
OPEN, by John Feinstein. (Little, Brown, $25.95.) The author of "A Good Walk
Spoiled" reports on the 2002 United States Open, held at the Bethpage Black golf
course on Long Island.
DERELICTION OF DUTY, by Robert (Buzz) Patterson. (Regnery, $27.95.) A
retired Air Force colonel who served in the White House contends that Bill Clinton
"compromised America's national security."
CHARLIE WILSON'S WAR, by George Crile. (Atlantic Monthly, $26.) A chronicle,
by a veteran producer for "60 Minutes," of a congressman's efforts in the 1980's to
steer billions to the anti-Soviet side in Afghanistan.
OFF WITH THEIR HEADS, by Dick Morris. (ReganBooks/HarperCollins, $24.95.)
The television analyst condemns what he describes as a campaign by politicians,
cultural figures and the news media "to oppose and impede the war on terror."
LEAP OF FAITH, by Queen Noor. (Miramax, $25.95.) An autobiography by the
widow of King Hussein of Jordan.
A PATRIOT'S HANDBOOK, selected by Caroline Kennedy. (Hyperion, $27.95.)
Essays, letters, speeches, poems and song lyrics that celebrate America.
